title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" is also known as the Health Insurance Availability for Children Act. It amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide health insurance availability for children. Subtitle L--Health Insurance Availability for Children, CHAPTER 101--Health Insurance Availability for Children, Sec. 9901 - Excise tax on failure to meet requirement of access to coverage, Sec. 9902 - Requirement of access to coverage, Sec. 9903 - Definitions. Imposition of Tax: A tax is imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of each premium received for group health plan failures. The tax imposed on group health plans for failures is 25 percent of each premium received. For self-insured plans, the cost of coverage is considered the premium for tax purposes. For self-insured group health plans, the cost of coverage is treated as the premium received for tax purposes. If an insurer offering individual health insurance coverage fails, a tax of 25 percent is imposed on the total premiums paid for the coverage in the plan year. For self-insured group health plans, the cost of coverage is treated as the premium received for tax purposes. If an insurer offering individual health insurance coverage fails, a tax of 25 percent is imposed on the total premiums paid for the coverage in the plan year. No tax is imposed if the failure was not discovered despite reasonable diligence. No tax is imposed under subsection (a) if the failure is corrected within 30 days and was due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. If a failure to pay tax is due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect, and corrected within 30 days of discovery, the Secretary may waive part or all of the tax imposed. The Secretary may waive part or all of the tax imposed for failures due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. The tax does not apply to governmental or church plans. Those responsible for the tax are specified. Liability for Tax: The tax imposed by subsection (a) is the responsibility of the group health plan for (a)(1) and the insurer offering health insurance coverage for (a)(2). "Requirement of access to coverage under SEC. 9902." Each group health plan must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants. The offer should be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and annually thereafter. Health insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age. Each insurer in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age, residing in the US, and a citizen or national (or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law). Qualifying coverage includes health care benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions. Qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 must include Medicare benefits without pre-existing condition limitations or waiting periods. The text discusses the coinsurance limits for Medicare benefits under parts A and B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act, ensuring that the coinsurance does not exceed a certain amount for specific services. Additionally, it mentions the payment for well child care benefits. Payment for newborn and well-baby care, including pediatrician services for high-risk deliveries, and well-child care benefits without deductibles, coinsurance, or copayments. The curr_chunk discusses well-child care benefits, including routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care, with a periodicity schedule to be established by the Secretary in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, will establish a periodicity schedule for preventive dental care services for healthy children. Managed care providers are not limited in delivering these benefits. For qualifying young dependents under 21 years old in the United States, they must be citizens, nationals, or aliens permanently residing in the US to receive certain benefits. Managed care providers have the flexibility to deliver these benefits as long as there is reasonable access. SEC. 9903. DEFINITIONS. "In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage described in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to benefits for medical care under any hospital or medical service policy or plan." The term 'health insurance coverage' includes medical benefits provided through hospital or medical service policies, contracts, or plans offered by insurers or health maintenance organizations, excluding coverage for accident or credit-only policies. The term 'health insurance coverage' includes medical benefits provided through hospital or medical service policies, contracts, or plans offered by insurers or health maintenance organizations, excluding coverage for accident, credit-only, vision, disability income, long-term care, nursing home care, community-based care dental, on-site medical clinics, or employee assistance programs, or any combination thereof. The term 'health insurance coverage' includes Medicare supplemental health insurance, similar supplemental coverage under a group health plan, coverage issued as a supplement to liability insurance, and liability insurance such as general liability and automobile insurance. The term 'health insurance coverage' includes Medicare supplemental health insurance, similar supplemental coverage under a group health plan, workers' compensation or similar insurance, automobile medical-payment insurance, coverage for a specified disease or illness, and hospital or fixed indemnity insurance. The term 'health insurance coverage' includes various types of insurance such as coverage for a specified disease or illness, hospital or fixed indemnity insurance, and short-term limited duration insurance. Other comparable coverage may also be specified in regulations. The term 'health maintenance organization' includes federally qualified organizations, those recognized under State law, or similar organizations regulated by the State. The term 'insurer' refers to an insurance company, service, or organization regulated under State law for solvency similar to a health maintenance organization. The term 'insurer' is defined as an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to do business in a State and regulated under State law. The term 'individual market' refers to health insurance coverage offered to individuals, excluding coverage offered through employers or group health plans. The terms 'beneficiary' and 'participant' have meanings as defined in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The terms 'beneficiary' and 'participant' have specific meanings under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, based on affiliation with an association. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Subtitle L. Health Insurance Availability for Children. The requirement of section 9902 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall take effect on January 1, 1998, and apply to coverage offered on or after that date. Refundable tax credit for purchase of health coverage for children. Refundable tax credit for purchasing health coverage for children under section 35 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A tax credit of 80% of qualified health premiums paid by an individual in a taxable year is allowed against the tax imposed. The credit is applied at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. The tax credit is applied at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability, which includes the tax imposed by this chapter and the taxpayer's social security taxes for the taxable year. The tax credit is applied at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability, including the taxes imposed by sections 3101 and 3201(a) on amounts received. The tax credit for a taxpayer in a taxable year includes taxes on received amounts, self-employment income, and certain other taxes. The tax credit for a taxpayer in a taxable year includes one-half of the taxes imposed on received amounts and coordination with special refund of social security taxes under section 6413(c). The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for special refund under section 6413(c). Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates are treated as taxes under this section. Definitions are provided for clarity. The term 'qualified health premium' refers to payments for health coverage of a qualifying young dependent, with definitions provided for 'health coverage' and 'qualifying young dependent'. The term 'health coverage' refers to health insurance that includes qualifying coverage. A 'qualifying young dependent' is defined in the context of health coverage. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997 for the purchase of health coverage for children and overpayments of tax.
